docs.title: Setting Up a Python Virtual Environment on macOS
docs.text:
A Python virtual environment (venv) is an isolated environment where you can install packages and dependencies without affecting the system-wide Python installation.

This guide covers the steps to set up and use a virtual environment on macOS.

docs.title: Quick Virtual Environment Commands (macOS)
docs.text: Command Description python3 --version Check installed Python version python3 -m venv .venv Create a virtual environment source .venv/bin/activate Activate the virtual environment which python Check the active Python interpreter pip install package-name Install a package inside the environment deactivate Exit the virtual environment rm -rf .venv Remove the virtual environment

docs.title: 1. Check Python Installation
docs.text:
Ensure Python is installed on your system:

python3 --version

If Python is not installed, install it via Homebrew:

brew install python3

docs.title: 2. Create a Project Folder and Virtual Environment
docs.text:
Create a new folder in your preferred location.

Drag the folder to VS Code icon to open the folder in VS Code

Use the Command Control+Shift+` or Click Terminal->New Terminal in the Menu Bar to access the terminal

Run the following command to create your virtual environment. Replace your_environment_name to your preferred environment name

python3 -m venv your_environment_name

This will create a your_environment_name folder in your project directory containing an isolated Python environment.

docs.title: 3. Activate the Virtual Environment
docs.text:
To activate the virtual environment, run:

source your_environment_name/bin/activate

Once activated, your terminal prompt will change to indicate that you are inside the virtual environment.

docs.title: 4. Install Packages Inside the Virtual Environment
docs.text:
To install a package, use pip:

pip install matplotlib

All installed packages will now reside inside .venv and will not affect your system-wide Python installation. To check if matplotlib got installed, run the following command to find all the installed packages:

pip list

docs.title: 5. Deactivate the Virtual Environment
docs.text:
To exit the virtual environment after completion and return to the system-wide Python installation, run:

deactivate

docs.title: ** Deploy a Python Streamlit App to Streamlit Cloud**
docs.text: This guide walks you through writing a Streamlit app, connecting to GitHub, and deploying it to Streamlit Cloud in simple steps.

docs.title: 📌 Step 1: Write a Simple Streamlit App in VS Code
1️⃣ Install Python & Streamlit
docs.text:
Before writing code, ensure Python is installed. Download it from: 🔗 Python Official Website

Next, open VS Code, launch a terminal using Terminal->New Terminal, create a virtual environment in python using Creating Python Virtual Environment and install Streamlit using the following command:

pip install streamlit

docs.title: 2️⃣ Create a Python File
docs.text:
• Open VS Code.
  • Create a new folder for your project.
  • Inside the folder, create a Python file, e.g., app.py.
  • Add this simple Streamlit app:
import streamlit as st

st.title("🚀 My First Streamlit App")
st.write("Hello, Streamlit Community!")

docs.title: 3️⃣ Run the App Locally
docs.text:
To test the app before deployment, run:

streamlit run app.py

This should open a local webpage showing your app. If everything works, proceed to the next step.

docs.title: 📌 Step 2: Upload Your Code to GitHub
1️⃣ Create a GitHub Account
docs.text: 🔗 Sign up on GitHub (if you don't have an account).

docs.title: 2️⃣ Initialize a Git Repository in VS Code
docs.text:
• Open VS Code terminal in your project folder.
  • Run the following commands to initialize Git:
git init
git add .
git commit -m "Initial commit"

docs.title: 3️⃣ Create a GitHub Repository
docs.text:
• Go to GitHub → Click New Repository.
  • Give it a name, e.g., streamlit-app.
  • Select Public (required for Streamlit Cloud).
  • Click Create Repository.

docs.title: 4️⃣ Connect VS Code to GitHub & Push Code
docs.text:
• Back in VS Code terminal, run:
git remote add origin https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/streamlit-app.git
git branch -M main
git push -u origin main

Now your code is on GitHub! ✅

docs.title: 1️⃣ Sign in to Streamlit Cloud
docs.text:
• Go to Streamlit Community Cloud: 🔗 https://streamlit.io/cloud
  • Click "Sign in with GitHub".
  • Authorize Streamlit to access your GitHub account.

docs.title: 2️⃣ Create a New App
docs.text:
• Click "New App".
  • Select your GitHub repository (streamlit-app).
  • Choose the main branch.

docs.title: 3️⃣ Select Python Version & Advanced Settings
docs.text:
• Set Python Version (e.g., 3.9 or 3.10).
  • Click Advanced settings:
  • If your app requires external API keys, you can add secrets here.

docs.title: 📌 Step 4: Add API Keys & Secrets (If Needed)
docs.text: If your app requires secret keys (e.g., OpenAI API, database credentials), store them securely.

docs.title: 1️⃣ Create a .streamlit/secrets.toml File
docs.text:
In your project folder, create a .streamlit directory and inside it, a secrets.toml file:

[api_keys]
openai_key = "your-openai-api-key"
database_url = "your-database-url"

docs.title: 2️⃣ Add Secrets in Streamlit Cloud
docs.text:
• Go to Streamlit Cloud → Your App → Settings → Secrets.
  • Copy and paste the same .toml content there.

docs.title: 📌 Step 5: Finalize & Share
docs.text:
• Click Deploy and wait for Streamlit to set up your app.
  • Once done, Streamlit will provide a live URL to share your app.

Example: 🔗 https://your-username-streamlit-app.streamlit.app

docs.title: 🎉 Congratulations!
docs.text:
You have successfully: ✅ Written a Streamlit app in VS Code ✅ Pushed it to GitHub ✅ Deployed it on Streamlit Cloud ✅ Added secret keys securely

Now, you can share your app with anyone! 🚀
